availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Whitman probably prepared this manuscript of the poem sequence "Old Age Echoes" in late 1890. His note at the top of an earlier manuscript of "The Unexpress'd" indicates that he had sent that poem to Harper's Magazine in October 1890, but it was rejected. A corrected proof of the poems on this manuscript is now in the the Charles E. Feinberg Collection at the Library of Congress (loc.00228) and bears Whitman's note: "Proof sent me f'm Lippincotts & returned Jan: 6 '91—to go in March number next." The publication in Lippincott's substituted the poem "Sail Out for Good, Eidólon Yacht!" for the engraving.

div1.head: Old Age Echoes—

lg.head: Sounds of the winter
lg.l:
Sunshine upon the mountains—many a distant
strain

From cheery rail-road train—from nearer field,
barn, house,

The whispering air—even the mute crops, gar-garner'd
ner'd apples, corn,

Children's and women's tones—rhythm of many
a farmer and of flail,

An old man's garrulous lips among the rest, think
not we give out yet.

l.hi: Forth from these snowy hairs we too keep up the lilt

lg.head: The Unexpress'd—
lg.l: After the cycles, poems, singers, plays,

Vaunted Ionia's, India's—Homer, ShakspereShakespeare—the long,
long times' thick dotted roads, areas,

The shining clusters and the Milky Ways of
stars—Nature's pulses reap'd

All retrospective passions, heros, war, love,
adoration,
All ages' plummets dropt to their utmost depths,

All human lives, throats, wishes, brains—all
experiences' found utterance

After the countless songs, or long or short, all tongues
all lands

Still something not yet told in poesy's voice
or print—something lacking,
(Who knows? the best yet unexpress'd and lacking.)

figure.head: Walt Whitman
figure.note: Both the engraving and the signature have been pasted on.

div1.note: put in type for greater correction & my own convenience

lg.l:
A group of weechildren with their ways and
chatter flow in.

Like welcome rippling water o'er my heated
nerves and flesh.
